Tax Cuts of 2023 Act

HB 3-088

Author: Westray

7 Dec 2023

Opening Declaration

  1. The purpose of this bill is to bring reforms to the existing tax code that was previously passed in 2022. This bill specifically targets the monthly balance tax, slightly reducing the amount of tax for Harlonians in order to encourage greater economic growth.
  2. This bill also introduces a minor property tax, through an excess tax levied on the largest property owners. This is done because an automatic tax isn’t currently possible. This alternative is the most fair way of preventing property monopolies, reducing taxes on the middle class,  and encouraging greater use of commercial spaces.

Information

  1. This act hereby amends the Tax and Revenue Reforms of 2022 Act to reflect adjusted balance tax brackets, and to introduce an excess property tax.
  2. As noted in the Tax and Revenue Reforms of 2022 Act, all revenue from taxes must go to the HarlonGov balance unless otherwise determined by the government. In addition, the 2% sales tax will continue to be levied respectively
  3. This act will introduce an excess tax on commercial property (defined by the “shop” code)  within Harlon City. Adding the following to the tax code:
  1. This tax will be applied to property owners based on information obtained in /arm listregions, and will be based on manual coordination at the end of each month.
  2. The amount will be based on the property owner’s balance, getting charged an additional tax on their balance after the original balance tax.
  3. Tax will be applied under the monthly rates of:
  1. 15 or more commercial properties, 2% additional
  2. 20  or more commercial properties, 4% additional
  3. 40 or more  commercial properties, 6% additional

  1. The balance tax will change by the following:

Old Bracket

Over £1000000

16%

Over £1000000

13%

Implementation and timeline

  1. This bill will require staff to modify the current tax brackets.
  2. This bill will require government and staff to levy the excess tax
  3. This bill shall take effect on January 1, 2024.

Other Information
